TEXT.P: Well, hello!

Lawyers, court clerks, and judges tend to write using jargon, complex sentence structures, and ancient document formatting. These lessons will teach you some methods you can use to write more clearly.

P.I: Before you continue, grab a piece of writing you have created. This can be a letter you have written, or a brochure you hand out to clients. For this exercise, you should be able to open it using Microsoft Word.

P.B: Plain Language School : Lesson 1 : Analyze a Document for Readability

TEXT.P: Avoid bewildering your readers! Your document may look like this to readers if it isn't written in plain language.
A readable document should be close to the 5th or 6th grade reading level, which is the average American's reading proficiency. To find the reading grade level (RGL), follow these steps:
1. Open your document in Microsoft Word.
2. Go to Word Preferences,and then to Spelling and Grammar.
3. Make sure the Check Grammarand Show Readability Statisticsboxes are checked.
4. Run a Spelling and Grammarcheck on your document.
5. At the end of the check, a box showing your document's readability statistics will pop up. The Flesch-Kincaid Grade Leveltells you your document's RGL.
This is just one of many tools that will help you think about the readability of the documents you create.
Thanks! That's the end of Lesson One.

QUESTION.P: Is the title positionin the top left-hand corner of the page?

FEEDBACK.P: Great! The reader expects to find the title in the top left-hand corner of a document.
Move the title to its natural location. The reader expects to find the title in the top left-hand corner of a document.

QUESTION.P: Ask someone who knows nothing about the topic of your document to look at it for 30 seconds. Then ask him or her what the document is about.
Is the purposeof your document immediately obvious to the reader?

FEEDBACK.P: Your reader is more likely to use this document if she can quickly understand its purpose. Try this technique:
If the title alonedoes not communicate what this document is about, add a short promptunder the title that explains

UL.LI: Who the document is for
The purpose of the document

FEEDBACK.P: Here is an example:

Before:URGENT COMMUNCATION: The Board has made regulatory changes that licensees should be aware of. The Board's Executive Officer or his/her selected official can now immediately suspend a license to protect the public's health and safety.
After:The Board can suspend your license immediately if we believe it is necessary to protect public health and safety.
Many readers will not even try to read a document if the title doesn't inform them of the document's purpose.
Great!
Consider ways to fix this.

QUESTION.P: Does your document contain large blocks of text?

FEEDBACK.P: To make your document easier to read, follow these rules:

UL.LI: Chunktext into small paragraphs to make the reading more manageable.
Use bulleted and numbered liststo break up text and help the reader quickly find the main messages.
If possible, present the text in 2-column format. Readers capture more text when there are fewer than 70 characters per line.

FEEDBACK.P: Great! Text that is split into sections is easier on the eyes. Readers often skip text buried in the middle of a large block of text.
Text that is notsplit into sections is hard on the eyes and the text in the middle of a large block of test is typically notread.

PAGE.PICTURE: One long block of text, and then the same text broken into paragraphs.

QUESTION.P: Does your document contain informative subheadingsto guide the reader?

FEEDBACK.P: Subheads help the reader to:

UL.LI: Identify which parts of the document apply to him or her,
Navigate to certain topics easily, and
Quickly understand the topics covered.

FEEDBACK.P: Subheads are also easier on the reader's eyes because they:

UL.LI: Create more white space on the page, and
Split up large chunks of text.

FEEDBACK.P: Tip:More than 50% of readers of brochures read onlythe headings and subheads. Put your important information there. Use bold font for subheads, and if space allows, make them 1 pt larger than the body text.
Great!
It may be a good idea to add subheads to your document.

QUESTION.P: Is the information in the order that makes sense to the reader?

UL.LI: Order intuitively – Put the information in the order your reader should read it.
Avoid cross-references –If you need to define a term or explain a concept, do so when you introduce the concept.
Use numbers for each question on a form.

QUESTION.P: We sometimes use text enhancementswith the hope that readers will notice certain parts of our document.
Are there long phrases or sentences that are underlined, italicized, boldface, or in reverse text?

FEEDBACK.P: Bold:Use sparingly: a word, phrase, a short sentence.
Italic:Use for emphasis and foreign words.
Underline, strike-out: Only as editing tools.
Reverse text: Pretty, but does not copy/fax well.

QUESTION.P: Does your document contain phrases or sentences that are written in ALL CAPS?

FEEDBACK.P: When overused, writing with CAPS makes it harder for the reader to identify where the key information is. Instead, use limited bold or italic for the key words.
If you aren't convinced, make any paragraph in your document all caps, and paste your all-caps paragraph right above the same paragraph with normal formatting. Which paragraph is easier to read?
CAPS are difficult to read, and should be avoided.
Great! CAPS are difficult to read, and should be avoided.

TEXT.P: Let’s recheck the reading grade level (RGL) of your document. Is the new RGL close to the 5th – 6th grade level?
Follow these steps to find out:
1. Open your document in Microsoft Word.
2. Go to Word Preferences and then to Spelling and Grammar.
3. Make sure the Check grammar and Show Readability Statistics boxes are checked.
4. Run a spelling and grammar check on your document.
5. At the end of the check, a box showing your document’s readability statistics will pop up. The Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level tells you your document’s reading grade level.

QUESTION.P: Does your document use serifor fancy displayfonts? ( Serifletters have fine cross strokes at the end of the lines.)

FEEDBACK.P:
To optimize readability, replace unusual and seriffonts (like Times New Roman) with a common sans seriffonts, such as Arial.
Sans seriffonts:

UL.LI: Are easier to read than serif fonts
Scan, fax, and print more legibly

FEEDBACK.P: Tip: Some older readers, who learned to read using seriffonts, might prefer seriffonts.
These may fatigue some readers more quickly than other fonts.
Great!

First, let's think about the reading skills of people who must read the forms, orders, and affidavits that we create.
What is the reading grade level of the average native English speaker in America?

FEEDBACK.P: Popular tools and instruments such as the Flesch-Kincaid(tm) scale and the Gunning Fog Index use grade level as the method to express document reading ease. The average reading grade level in the United States is about the 5th or 6th grade level.
Correct.
That is incorrect.

It seems that many variables might affect what should be considered "grade level" reading, including fluctuations in the effectiveness of teaching and the skill levels of students nationwide. But grade level assessment has more quantitative, industry-wide meaning than you might have guessed.
